unnormalised: Heart health is something we often take for granted, isn't it? We go about our daily lives, munching on samosas and running around like crazy, without really thinking about our ticker. But Cardiology, the branch of medicine that deals with the heart, wants you to pay attention! It's not just for older folks; heart problems can sneak up on anyone, even youngsters like my nephew, Rohan. He was shocked when Dr. Desai told him his BP was 140/90.
normalised: Heart health is something we often take for granted, isn't it? We go about our daily lives, munching on samosas and running around like crazy, without really thinking about our ticker. But Cardiology, the branch of medicine that deals with the heart, wants you to pay attention! It's not just for older folks; heart problems can sneak up on anyone, even youngsters like my nephew, Rohan. He was shocked when Doctor Desai told him his B-P was one hundred and forty over ninety.

unnormalised: One of the big things cardiologists deal with is heart disease. This can manifest in many ways, from high BP (mentioned earlier) to more serious stuff like heart attacks (Myocardial Infarction, or MI) and strokes. Understanding your cholesterol levels is also crucial. You've probably heard of LDL and HDL – the "bad" and "good" cholesterol, respectively. A simple blood test at your local diagnostic centre, maybe costing around Rs. 500, can give you these numbers. My uncle had a scare last year; his LDL was over 160 mg/dL.
normalised: One of the big things cardiologists deal with is heart disease. This can manifest in many ways, from high B-P (mentioned earlier) to more serious stuff like heart attacks (Myocardial Infarction, or M-I) and strokes. Understanding your cholesterol levels is also crucial. You've probably heard of L-D-L and H-D-L – the "bad" and "good" cholesterol, respectively. A simple blood test at your local diagnostic centre, maybe costing around rupee five hundred, can give you these numbers. My uncle had a scare last year; his L-D-L was over one hundred and sixty milligram per deciliter.

unnormalised: So, what can you do? Well, lifestyle changes are key. Eating a healthy diet, low in oily foods and rich in fruits and vegetables, is a must. Exercise is also vital. You don't need to run a marathon; even a brisk walk for 30 minutes, 5 days a week, can make a big difference. My cousin, Priya, swears by her yoga sessions at 7 AM every morning. Also, if you're a smoker, quit! It's the absolute worst thing for your heart.
normalised: So, what can you do? Well, lifestyle changes are key. Eating a healthy diet, low in oily foods and rich in fruits and vegetables, is a must. Exercise is also vital. You don't need to run a marathon; even a brisk walk for thirty minutes, five days a week, can make a big difference. My cousin, Priya, swears by her yoga sessions at seven A-M every morning. Also, if you're a smoker, quit! It's the absolute worst thing for your heart.

unnormalised: Advances in cardiology are also helping a lot. Procedures like angioplasty and bypass surgery can save lives. My grandpa had an angioplasty at AIIMS Delhi last year after complaining of chest pain. The procedure involved inserting a stent to open up a blocked artery. The cost can vary, but it's generally around Rs. 2 lakh – 4 lakh, depending on the hospital.

The cost can vary, but it's generally around rupee two lakh to rupee four lakh, depending on the hospital.

unnormalised: Ultimately, taking care of your heart is about being proactive. Regular check-ups with your doctor, especially if you have a family history of heart disease, are essential. Don't ignore symptoms like chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations. Remember, your heart is a precious organ, and it deserves your attention. So, go ahead, make a cup of chai (but maybe skip the sugar this time!) and think about how you can give your ticker some love.
